As he works his way to restore his old timeline, Barry must also contend with [[Professor Zoom]], who appears to be behind everything. The film was released on DVD and Blu-Ray July 30, 2013 and is based on the comic book series “[[Flashpoint (comics)|Flashpoint]]” by [[Geoff Johns]]. ===''Justice League: War'' (2014)=== {{Main article|Justice League: War}} During an investigation in Gotham City, [[Batman|Bruce Wayne / Batman]] encounters [[Green Lantern|Hal Jordan / Green Lantern]] who together discover a motherbox which prompts [[Superman|Clark Kent / Superman]] to attack the duo. They later meet [[Wonder Woman|Diana Prince / Wonder Woman]], [[Flash (Barry Allen)|Barry Allen / The Flash]], [[Cyborg (comics)|Victor Stone / Cyborg]] and [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Billy Batson / Shazam]] to team up and take down the posing threat of [[Darkseid]]. The film was released on January 21, 2014 and is based on the comic book “Justice League: Origin” by Geoff Johns and [[Jim Lee]]. It features the voice talents of Jason O'Mara as [[Batman]], Alan Tudyk as [[Superman]], Michelle Monaghan as [[Wonder Woman]], Christopher Gorham as [[The Flash]], Justin Kirk as [[Green Lantern]], Shemar Moore as [[Cyborg (comics)|Cyborg]], Sean Astin as [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Shazam]], Steven Blum as [[Darkseid]], and Rocky Carroll as Dr. Silas Stone.{{cite web|title=Justice League: War|url=http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/dcuam/justiceleaguewar/backstage/castcrew.php|website=The World's Finest|accessdate=August 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810234024/http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/dcuam/justiceleaguewar/backstage/castcrew.php|archive-date=August 10, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} It is the first film in the DC Animated Movie Universe.{{cite web|title=Justice League: War Kicks Off New DC Animated Universe|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/131954-Justice-League-War-Kicks-Off-New-DC-Animated-Universe|last=Lemon|first=Marshall|website=[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]|date=February 3, 2014|accessdate=August 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822073026/http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/131954-Justice-League-War-Kicks-Off-New-DC-Animated-Universe|archive-date=August 22, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} A sequel to the film, ''[[Justice League: Throne of Atlantis]]'', was released January 13, 2015. ===''Son of Batman'' (2014)=== {{Main article|Son of Batman}} Bruce Wayne discovers he has a violent son named [[Damian Wayne|Damian]] who was raised by a secret organisation called the [[League of Assassins]] led by [[Ra’s al Ghul]]. Meanwhile, [[Deathstroke|Slade Wilson / Deathstroke]] hunts down Damian for revenge because he took his place as heir to the demon. The film was released on April 22, 2014 and is based on the comic book “[[Batman and Son]]” by [[Grant Morrison]] and [[Andy Kubert]]. The film introduces [[Damian Wayne]] to the universe. A sequel to the film, ''[[Batman vs. Robin]]'', was released on April 22, 2015. ===''Justice League: Throne of Atlantis'' (2015)=== {{Main article|Justice League: Throne of Atlantis}} When Atlantean warriors attack Gotham, [[Aquaman|Arthur Curry / Aquaman]] must team up with the [[Justice League]] to stop his evil brother, [[Ocean Master|Orm Marius / Ocean Master]], who leads the attack, and also plans to steal the throne of [[Atlantis (DC Comics)|Atlantis]] for himself. The film was released on January 13, 2015 and is based on comic book “[[Throne of Atlantis]]” by Geoff Johns and [[Ivan Reis]]. The film introduces [[Aquaman]] to the universe. ===''Batman vs. Robin'' (2015)=== {{Main article|Batman vs. Robin}} Batman trains his son Damian to become a new version of [[Damian Wayne|Robin]] although doesn’t completely agree with his father’s “No Killing” rule and believes his own destiny lies within a secret society. The film was released on April 7, 2015. The film features the [[Court of Owls]]. The film is loosely based on the comic book “Batman: The Court of Owls”. A sequel to the film, ''[[Batman: Bad Blood]]'', was released in January 2016 ===''Batman: Bad Blood'' (2016)=== {{Main article|Batman: Bad Blood}} With Bruce Wayne missing, [[Dick Grayson]] takes up the mantle of Batman but finds himself teaming up with Damian Wayne and the mysterious [[Batwoman]] and [[Batwing (DC Comics)|Batwing]] to face a new threat involving the mysterious [[Leviathan (DC Comics)|Heretic]] and Damian's mother [[Talia al Ghul]]. The film was released on January 20, 2016. It features an original story by [[J.M. DeMatteis]]. It introduces Batwoman and Batwing to the universe.{{cite web|title=Batman: The Killing Joke Gets an Animated Adaptation|url=http://www.dccomics.com/blog/2015/07/10/batman-the-killing-joke-gets-an-animated-adaptation|last=Beedle|first=Tim|publisher=DC Comics|date=July 10, 2015|accessdate=August 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160627193925/http://www.dccomics.com/blog/2015/07/10/batman-the-killing-joke-gets-an-animated-adaptation|archive-date=June 27, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=NYCC: Cast of "Batman: Bad Blood" Reveal First Footage|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/nycc-cast-of-batman-bad-blood-reveal-first-footage|website=Comic Book Resources|last=Manning|first=Shaun|accessdate=August 21, 2016|date=October 10, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331065233/http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/nycc-cast-of-batman-bad-blood-reveal-first-footage|archive-date=March 31, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ===''Justice League vs. Teen Titans'' (2016)=== {{Main article|Justice League vs. Teen Titans}} Batman encourages Damian to join a group of young heroes known as the [[Teen Titans]] lead by [[Starfire (Teen Titans)|Koriand’r / Starfire]] that consist of [[Raven (DC Comics)|Raven]], [[Beast Boy]], and [[Blue Beetle]]. Meanwhile, a demon known as [[Trigon (comics)|Trigon]] possesses the Justice League who are forced to be confronted by the Titans. The film premiered at [[WonderCon]] in Los Angeles on March 26, 2016. It introduces the [[Teen Titans]] to the universe.{{cite web|title=Justice League vs. Teen Titans to Premiere at WonderCon|url=http://www.superherohype.com/news/364627-justice-league-vs-teen-titans-to-premiere-at-wondercon|last=Perry|first=Spencer|website=SuperHeroHype|accessdate=August 21, 2016|date=February 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017100209/http://www.superherohype.com/news/364627-justice-league-vs-teen-titans-to-premiere-at-wondercon|archive-date=October 17, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} It features an original story by [[Bryan Q. Miller]]. ===''Justice League Dark'' (2017)=== {{Main article|Justice League Dark (film)}} After a series of demonic attacks over Gotham, Batman and the Justice League request [[John Constantine]] for help who recruits a team of supernatural heroes consisting of [[Zatanna]], [[Deadman (DC Comics)|Boston Brand / Deadman]], [[Etrigan the Demon|Jason Blood / Etrigan the Demon]] and [[Swamp Thing|Alec Holland / Swamp Thing]] to stop it. The film was released April 4, 2017 and is based on the comic book "[[The Judas Contract]]" by [[Marv Wolfman]] and [[George Perez]]. ===''Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay'' (2018)=== {{main|Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay}} [[Amanda Waller]] recruits a team of criminals known as [[Task Force X]] which consists of [[Deadshot|Floyd Lawton / Deadshot]], [[Harley Quinn|Harleen Quinzel / Harley Quinn]], [[Captain Boomerang|George Harkness / Captain Boomerang]], [[Bronze Tiger|Ben Turner / Bronze Tiger]], [[Copperhead (DC Comics)|Sameer Park / Copperhead]] and [[Killer Frost|Crystal Frost / Killer Frost]] to retrieve a mystical object while they are confronted by other villainous masterminds who are also after that artifact, including an immortal being known as [[Vandal Savage]] and [[Eobard Thawne|Zoom]]. It features an original story by [[Alan Burnett]] and "what’s promised to be an amazing voice cast".{{cite web|title=Upcoming DC animated movies announced at Comic-Con|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/dvd/news/872455-upcoming-dc-animated-movies-announced-at-comic-con|website=ComingSoon.net|date=July 22, 2017|accessdate=July 22, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170725012238/http://www.comingsoon.net/dvd/news/872455-upcoming-dc-animated-movies-announced-at-comic-con|archive-date=July 25, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ===''The Death of Superman'' (2018)=== {{Main|The Death of Superman (film)}} When a monster, nicknamed [[Doomsday (DC Comics)|Doomsday]], crashes down to Earth, it begins a destructive rampage which triggers the [[Justice League]] and later [[Lex Luthor]] to come and stop it. When all attempts fail, they come to realization they need [[Superman]] to kill it. Despite the story being previously adapted in the first animated movie (though not in the DCAMU), ''[[Superman: Doomsday]]'', this said movie greatly altered and condensed the original comic story to fit it within a 75-minute runtime. ''The Death of Superman'' was written to be much more faithful to the original story; according to DC's Tim Beedle, the film is "much less condensed and will include many of the fan-favorite moments from the story that were left out of ''Doomsday''".{{cite web|last1=Beedle|first1=Tim|title=The Death and Return of Superman Gets a Two-Part Animated Movie|url=https://www.dccomics.com/blog/2017/07/21/the-death-and-return-of-superman-gets-a-two-part-animated-movie|publisher=[[DC Comics]]|accessdate=April 16, 2018|date=July 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180417025118/https://www.dccomics.com/blog/2017/07/21/the-death-and-return-of-superman-gets-a-two-part-animated-movie|archive-date=April 17, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ===''Constantine: City of Demons'' (2018)=== {{Main|Constantine: City of Demons}} A decade after a tragic mistake, family man Chas and occult detective John Constantine set out to cure Chas’s daughter Trish from a mysterious supernatural coma. ''City of Demons'' is a film version of the [[Constantine: City of Demons|web series of the same name]], itself based on the graphic novel ''[[All His Engines]]''.{{cite web |last1=Trumbore |first1=Dave |title=New Trailer for ‘Constantine: City of Demons’ Heralds the Animated Movie’s Blu-ray Arrival |url=http://collider.com/constantine-city-of-demons-trailer/ |website=Collider |date=August 1, 2018 |accessdate=August 27, 2018}} The film premiered at [[New York Comic Con]] on October 4, 2018,{{Cite news|url=https://www.dccomics.com/blog/2018/09/26/john-constantines-new-movie-gets-a-nycc-premiere|title=John Constantine's New Movie Gets a NYCC Premiere|last=Beedle|first=Time|date=September 26, 2018|work=DC|access-date=}} and released on Blu-ray, DVD, and digital on October 9, 2018. ==Upcoming film== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:99%;" |- ! The film will feature [[Superboy (Kon-El)|Superboy]], [[Steel (John Henry Irons)|Steel]], the [[Eradicator (comics)|Eradicator]] and [[Cyborg Superman]].{{cite web |last1=Beddle |first1=Tim |title=The Death and Return of Superman Gets a Two-Part Animated Movie |url=https://www.dccomics.com/blog/2017/07/21/the-death-and-return-of-superman-gets-a-two-part-animated-movie |publisher=DC Comics |date=July 1, 2017 |accessdate=August 27, 2018}} It will be released digitally on January 15, 2019, and on Blu-ray January 29.{{cite web|last1=Burlingame|first1=Russ|title='Reign of the Supermen' Gets January Release Date|url=https://comicbook.com/dc/2018/10/24/reign-of-the-supermen-gets-january-release-date/|publisher=[[comicbook.com/dc]]|accessdate=October 24, 2018|date=October 24, 2018}} ==Short film== ===''Nightwing and Robin'' (2015)=== ''Nightwing and Robin'' is a one-minute short film set during the events of ''Justice League: Throne of Atlantis''.{{cite web|title=Justice League: Throne of Atlantis|url=http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/dcuam/throneofatlantis/backstage/nightwingrobin/|website=The World's Finest|accessdate=August 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823182714/http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/dcuam/throneofatlantis/backstage/nightwingrobin/|archive-date=August 23, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- ! style="width:14%;" | Character ! style="width:10%;" | ''[[Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox|Justice League:

Release date | February 4, 2014 | May 6, 2014 | January 27, 2015 | April 14, 2015 | February 2, 2016 | April 12, 2016 | February 7, 2017 | April 18, 2017 | March 27, 2018 | July 24, 2018 |} ==In other media== ===Comic books=== ====''Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay''==== The digital-first series ''Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay'' was released on March 21, 2018, and features 12 digital issues. It serves as a sequel to film of [[Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay|the same name]].{{cite web|title="Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay" gets sequel comic ahead of video release|url=https://batman-news.com/2018/03/21/suicide-squad-hell-to-pay-gets-sequel-comic-ahead-of-video-release/|last=Yaws|first=Jay|website=Batman News|accessdate=May 14, 2018|date=March 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180515043528/https://batman-news.com/2018/03/21/suicide-squad-hell-to-pay-gets-sequel-comic-ahead-of-video-release/|archive-date=May 15, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=DC Releases Comic Book Sequel to Animated Suicide Squad Film a Week Before Movie Comes Out|url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2018/03/21/dc-sequel-animated-suicide-squad/|last=Terror|first=Jude|website=Bleeding Cool|accessdate=May 14, 2018|date=March 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180514213537/https://www.bleedingcool.com/2018/03/21/dc-sequel-animated-suicide-squad/|archive-date=May 14, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ====''The Death of Superman: Part 1''==== On August 1, 2018, DC announced a 12-part, weekly digital comic series titled ''The Death of Superman: Part 1''.{{cite web|url=https://www.dccomics.com/blog/2018/08/01/dc-announces-a-comic-tie-in-series-for-death-of-superman-animated-movie-available|title=DC ANNOUNCES A COMIC TIE-IN SERIES FOR DEATH OF SUPERMAN ANIMATED MOVIE, AVAILABLE TODAY|date=August 1, 2018|publisher=[[DC Comics]]|accessdate=August 16, 2018}} This series, written by veteran Superman writer [[Louise Simonson]] serves as prequel to the film. Some aspects of the series contradict events previously established in the DC Animated Movie Universe, most notably the Parademon invasion as depicted in ''[[Justice League: War]]''. In the US, retailer [[Best Buy]] offered an exclusive "Deluxe Edition" Blu-ray containing a hardcover graphic novel titled ''The Death of Superman: The Wake'',{{cite web |url=https://www.bestbuy.com/site/the-death-of-superman-blu-ray-dvd-graphic-novel-only--best-buy-2018/6260232.p |title=The Death of Superman [Blu-ray/DVD] [Graphic Novel] [Only @ Best Buy] 2018 |last= |first= |date= |website=[[Best Buy]] |publisher= |access-date=August 27, 2018 |quote=}} which compiles the first four chapters of the series. ===Web series=== ====''Constantine: City of Demons''==== {{Main|Constantine: City of Demons}} ''[[Constantine: City of Demons]]'' is an [[animated series|animated web series]] from executive producers [[Greg Berlanti]] and [[David S. Goyer]] based on the [[DC Comics]] character [[John Constantine]], a demon hunter and [[Occult detective fiction|occult detective]]. According to [[J. M. DeMatteis]] the series is not a continuation of ''[[Constantine (TV series)|Constantine]]'', but is in the same universe as the 2017 film ''[[Justice League Dark (film)|Justice League Dark]]''. He added that "time will tell" whether the show is part of the [[Arrowverse]].{{cite tweet |last= DeMatteis |first=J.M. |user= JMDeMatteis|number= 979120312561356803|date= March 28, 2018|title= Not a continuation of the series. It IS in the same universe as the JL DARK movie and I guess time will tell if it's in the Arrowverse! |link= https://twitter.com/JMDeMatteis/status/979120312561356803|access-date= April 2, 2018}} ==Reception== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:99%; text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Film ! colspan="3"| [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |- ! {{Redirect|Dangler|an ambiguous grammatical construct|Dangling modifier}} '''Dangler''' is a literary term meaning a [[plotline]] that is metaphorically left to "dangle" or "hang". A ''dangler'', or ''dangling plotline'', is a [[plot device]] in fiction where a plotline is forgotten, phased out and eventually dropped, thus a resolution is never achieved. Although dangling plotlines can occur in all forms of media, they typically appear in comic books, movies and book sequels, where the original writer or creative team can be replaced.<ref>http://dollhousewiki.fox.com/thread/2975709/DOLLHOUSE+Season+1+WRAP-UP%3A+Top+10+Plot+Danglers!</ref><ref>http://www.uncannyxmen.net/db/article/showfaq.asp?fldAuto=18</ref><ref>http://dexterwiki.sho.com/page/Dexter%3A+Plot+Holes</ref>
== Reasons for danglers == Typically, a writer will pepper the main story with smaller back-stories. It then becomes evident to the reader that these smaller back-stories have the potential to build up into a bigger story and reach a conclusion of some sort.
Editorial mandate can also force a writer to drop a building plotline due to fan backlash or an editor's lack of interest to pursue such a plot.
== Examples of danglers == In [[television]], when a creative team fears that their show may not be picked up for another season, they will end the [[season finale]] with a [[cliffhanger]] in order to conjure a fan outcry and interest to continue the series. When the series is not picked up for another season, the cliffhanger creates a dangling plotline. Usually the original writer, fan of the series, or the company who produced the series, will look to another form of media to continue the story. ''[[Twin Peaks]]'' was able to resolve some dangling plotlines due to the release of the [[Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me|theatrical film]]. ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' got its own comic book series appropriately named ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]'', which was written by series creator [[Joss Whedon]].<ref>http://www.darkhorse.com/Comics/14-111/Buffy-the-Vampire-Slayer-Season-8-1</ref> In an extremely rare occasion, ''[[Futurama]]'' was continued six years later through [[direct-to-DVD]] films, which eventually led to the resurrection of the series in its original television format.<ref>http://www.speedbumpstudios.com/futurama/</ref>
In [[comic book]]s, it is a common practice for writers to resolve their own dangling plotlines in other comic books within the [[shared universe]]. A good example is [[Frank Tieri (comics)|Frank Tieri]], who started a [[Weapon X]] story in [[Wolverine (comic book)|Wolverine]], who then later became the writer of his own Weapon X series and as the series ended abruptly, was forced to continue some of his side-stories in a miniseries called ''Weapon X: Days of Future Now''.<ref>''Weapon X: Days of Future Now'' #1-5</ref> One lingering plotline left a character in limbo from the ''Weapon X'' series until Frank Tieri took the reins of ''[[New Excalibur]]'',<ref>New Excalibur #8-15</ref> where he proceeded to close this character's storyline, five years later. [[Chris Claremont]] and [[Warren Ellis]] are also known for continuing their own stories throughout other books they write for. In a similar fashion, [[Mark Millar]] has continued the story of an ever-dangling character, [[Clyde Wyncham]], all throughout his runs on ''[[Marvel 1985]]'', ''[[Kick-Ass (comic book)|Kick-Ass]]'', ''[[Fantastic Four]]'' and ''[[Old Man Logan]]''.
Because of the unsatisfying nature of having a plotline dangle, fans sometimes take matters into their own hands. One famous example of this, the numerous directors and writers in the ''[[Halloween (franchise)|Halloween]]'' series each had different directions for their story of [[Michael Myers (Halloween)|Michael Myers]]. This left many [[plot holes]] and dangling storylines after each movie. Seemingly unconnected, the movies would end with a cliffhanger and continue with absolutely no mention of the previous movie's occurrences. To remedy this mess of [[Continuity (fiction)|continuity]], [[Chaos Comics]] published a comic book series to bridge the gaps between all the movies into one continuous [[canon (fiction)|canon]].

{{More footnotes|date=August 2010}} '''Environmental sculpture''' is sculpture that creates or alters the environment for the viewer, as opposed to presenting itself figurally or monumentally before the viewer. A frequent trait of larger environmental sculptures is that one can actually enter or pass through the sculpture and be partially or completely surrounded by it. Also, in the same spirit, it may be designed to generate shadows or reflections, or to color the light in the surrounding area.<ref>[[Britannica]] Online: [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9032735/environmental-sculpture] '''"20th-century art form intended to involve or encompass the spectators rather than merely to face them; the form developed as part of a larger artistic current that sought to break down the historical dichotomy between life and art."'''</ref>
== Sculpture as environment == [[File:Eberhard Bosslet Intervention Bauzeichnung La Restinga II voll El Hierro 1983.jpg|thumb|right|[[Eberhard Bosslet]] construction drawing ''La Restinga II, El Hierro'', 1983]]
Julia M. Bush emphasizes the nonfigurative aspect of such works: "Environmental sculpture is never made to work at exactly human scale, but is sufficiently larger or smaller than scale to avoid confusion with the human image in the eyes of the viewer."<ref>(Busch, p. 27)."A Decade of Sculpture: the New Media in the 1960s" (1974)</ref> Ukrainian-born [[United States|American]] sculptor [[Louise Nevelson]] is a pioneer of environmental sculpture in this sense. Busch (p. 27) also places the sculptures of [[Jane Frank]], as well as some works by [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]] and [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]], in this category. Some environmental sculpture so encompasses the observer that it verges on architecture.
[[George Segal (artist)|George Segal]], [[Duane Hanson]], [[Edward Kienholz]], [[Robert Smithson]], [[Christo]], and [[Michael Heizer]] are well known practitioners of the genre, although Segal and Hanson's work is figural. Many figurative works of George Segal, for example, do qualify as environmental, in that—instead of being displayed on a pedestal as presentations to be gazed upon—they occupy and perturb the setting in which they are placed. A well known instance of this is the pair of Segal figures that sit on and stand next to one of the public benches in [[New York City]]'s Sheridan Square; anyone can sit amongst them.
A less known but more appropriate example is [[Athena Tacha]]'s {{convert|2|acre|m2|sing=on}} park ''Connections'' in downtown Philadelphia (between 18th St. and 19th St. two blocks north of Vine St.), created as a landscape art environment after her winning a competition in 1980 (where Segal was actually one of the finalists). It was the first park designed entirely by an artist "sculpting the land" with planted terraces, rock clusters and paths (completed in 1992).
==Sculpture created for an environment== <!-- File:Elena Paroucheva Source Flamme.jpg was removed because does not appear to be related to article. --> [[File:Lumen Poem 1985.jpg|thumb|''Lumen Poem'', by [[Jean-Max Albert]], 1985]] A second sense of the term "environmental sculpture", with a somewhat different emphasis, is sculpture ''created for'' a particular set of surroundings. Thus, contemporary sculptor Beth Galston writes: "An environmental sculptor plans a piece from the very beginning in relationship to its surroundings. The site is a catalyst, becoming part of the creative process."<ref>http://www.bethgalston.com/AboutEnvSculpt.htm</ref> This is quite different from a Nevelson sculpture, which can usually be moved from place to place, like a conventional sculpture, without losing its meaning and effectiveness.
By Galston's definition, an environmental sculpture is not merely [[site-specific art]] as many conventional, figurative, marble monuments were created for specific sites. Galston stresses that environmental sculpture entails the idea that the piece also functions to alter or permeate the existing environment or even to create a new environment in which the viewer is invited to participate: "The finished sculpture and site become one integrated unit, working together to create a unified mood or atmosphere," she writes. Many of the large, site-specific, [[minimalist]] sculptures of [[Richard Serra]] also qualify as environmental sculpture, in both senses described here. Much of what is called "[[land art]]" or "[[earth art]]" could also be termed environmental sculpture under this definition. [[Andrew Rogers (sculptor)|Andrew Rogers]] and [[Alan Sonfist]] (which see) are among notable current practitioners of [[land art]].
Since the mid-seventies, French artist [[Jean-Max Albert]] worked with [[trellis (architecture)|trellis]] structures, deconstructing and re-arranging the elements of surrounding architecture or including the site into the sculpture<ref>Bruno Suner,''Les sculptures de visées du Parc de La Villette'', Urbanisme no 215, 1986</ref> with [[Sculptures Bachelard]].
Since 1983 German artist [[Eberhard Bosslet]] makes interventions on ruins, so-called "Re/formations and side effects"; he refers to the conditions of industrial and residential buildings by white painted lines or black painted color fields. In 1999 the artist Elena Paroucheva created her concept for pylons, integrating energy networks with sculptures.http://www.art-elena.com/
==Site-specific art and environmental art== [[File:Spiral-jetty-from-rozel-point.png|thumb|right|''[[Spiral Jetty]]'' by [[Robert Smithson]] from atop Rozel Point, in mid-April 2005]] The term "[[site-specific art]]" is sometimes used interchangeably with "[[environmental art]]". [[Louise Nevelson]], for instance is a pioneer American environmental artist with sources disagreeing on classifying her work as "environmental sculpture". The terms "environment sculpture", "site-specific art", and "environmental art" have not yet completely stabilized in their meanings.
A reason for blurred definitions is that much of site-specific and environmental art was created from 1970 on for public spaces all over the United States, sponsored by federal (GSA and NEA) or state and city [[Percent for Art]] competitions, and many of the artists were women trying to succeed outside the established art-gallery world. Younger art historians will have to sort out the development of this marginalized "movement" and the importance of artists such as [[Olga Kisseleva]], [[Patricia Johanson]], [[Athena Tacha]], Mary Miss, [[Alice Adams (artist)|Alice Adams]], [[Elyn Zimmerman]], [[Merle Temkin]] and others who, from the early 1970s on, won and executed large outdoor public art commissions with new formal, kinesthetic and social underpinnings. Many of these artists were also ecologically conscious and created works that could offer a further definition of "environmental sculpture": art that is environmentally friendly and cares for the natural environment.

[[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]] | past_members = [[List of Exodus members]] }} '''Exodus''' is an American [[thrash metal]] band formed in 1979 in [[Richmond, California]].{{cite book |last = Wall |first = Mick |title = Enter Night: A Biography of Metallica (page 119) |publisher = [[St. Martin's Press]] |date = May 10, 2011 |isbn = 0-312-64989-4}} They have gone through numerous lineup changes, two extended hiatuses, and the deaths of two former band members. Their current lineup consists of guitarists [[Gary Holt (musician)|Gary Holt]] and [[Lee Altus]], bassist Jack Gibson, drummer [[Tom Hunting]], and lead vocalist [[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]]. Hunting is one of the original members, and departed from Exodus twice, in 1989 and 2004, but rejoined in 2007. Holt joined the band about two years after its formation, and is the only member of Exodus to appear on all their releases. Since its formation, Exodus has released ten studio albums, two live albums, one compilation album, and a [[Let There Be Blood|re-recording]] of their [[Bonded by Blood|first album]]. Along with [[Metallica]] (whose longtime lead guitarist [[Kirk Hammett]] was an original member of Exodus), [[Possessed (band)|Possessed]], [[Testament (band)|Testament]], [[Death Angel]], [[Vio-lence|Vio-Lence]], [[Forbidden (band)|Forbidden]] and [[Lȧȧz Rockit]], they are often credited as pioneers of the [[Bay Area thrash metal]] scene,{{cite web|title=Exodus To Release 'Blood In, Blood Out' Album In October|url=http://www2.gibson.com/News-Lifestyle/Shared/2011/June/Gibson-Interview-Kirk-Hammett-of-Metallica.aspx|work=[[Gibson Guitar Corporation|gibson.com]]|date=June 5, 2011|accessdate=October 12, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Legendary metal band Exodus, formed in Richmond, set to release 10th studio album|url=http://richmondstandard.com/2014/09/legendary-metal-band-exodus-formed-richmond-set-release-10th-studio-album/|work=richmondstandard.com|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=October 12, 2014}} and have sold over five million albums worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.thegauntlet.com/article/29011/Exodus-Announces-Hometown-Gig |title=Exodus Announces Hometown Gig - The Gauntlet Heavy Metal News |website=Thegauntlet.com |date=October 3, 2013 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} Exodus had particular success in the mid-to-late 1980s with their first three studio albums: ''[[Bonded by Blood]]'' (1985), ''[[Pleasures of the Flesh]]'' (1987) and ''[[Fabulous Disaster]]'' (1989). The critical praise given to ''Fabulous Disaster'' garnered attention from major labels, including [[Capitol Records]], with whom Exodus signed in 1989. The band released two more studio albums (''[[Impact Is Imminent]]'' in 1990 and ''[[Force of Habit]]'' in 1992) before disbanding in 1994. After temporarily reuniting in 1997–1998, Exodus reformed once again in 2001, and since then, they have released five more studio albums, the most recent being ''[[Blood In, Blood Out (Exodus album)|Blood In, Blood Out]]'' (2014). The band is currently writing a follow-up album, tentatively due for release in late 2019 or early 2020.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exoduss-next-album-will-be-very-violent-and-very-heavy/|title=EXODUS's Next Album Will Be 'Very Violent And Very Heavy'|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=August 6, 2018|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} ==History== ===Formation and early years (1979–1983)=== [[File:Gary Holt Slayer Kiev 03.JPG|thumb|right|Guitarist [[Gary Holt (musician)|Gary Holt]] has been a member of Exodus since 1981, and is the only member to have performed on all of the band's albums.]] The initial lineup of Exodus was formed in the late 1970s by guitarists [[Kirk Hammett]] and Tim Agnello, drummer/vocalist [[Tom Hunting]], and vocalist Keith Stewart, while they attended high school together. The band added bass guitarist Carlton Melson in 1980, and the quintet began making a name for themselves playing backyard parties and various school functions. They played mostly cover songs in the vein of 1970s hard rock and [[New wave of British heavy metal]] (NWOBHM) acts but also developed some of their own original songs. Stewart soon left the band and Hunting became the band's sole vocalist for some time. Carlton Melson was replaced in 1981 by bass guitarist Geoff Andrews.{{cite web|title=Carlton Melson interview|url=http://pestwebzine.com/index/carlton_melson/0-1457}} Tim Agnello would also leave the group, moving to New York City and staying involved in the music industry as a guitar player, manager, and writer.{{cite web|title=Tim Agnello interview|url=https://www.cmalliance.org/alife/you-can-call-me-al/}} This left Exodus to perform as a power trio until a replacement was found in Hammett's friend and Exodus roadie [[Gary Holt (musician)|Gary Holt]].{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gvMDgl0z_ZA|title = Exodus / Slayer's Gary Holt - Wikipedia: Fact or Fiction?|date = April 8, 2015|accessdate = November 18, 2015|website = YouTube|publisher = LoudWire|last = |first = }} Also in 1981, Hammett met El Cerrito resident [[Paul Baloff]] at a North Berkeley house party, a friendship that was started – according to Hammett – by their shared admiration for punk rock and 1970s heavy metal music. Baloff became the band's lead vocalist and the quintet recorded a 3-track demo tape in 1982 consisting of the songs "Whipping Queen", "Death and Domination" and "Warlord", a release which would be Hammett's only recording with Exodus. The band's music began to incorporate elements of [[hardcore punk]] into their NWOBHM roots, and Exodus were considered the pioneers of the [[Bay Area thrash metal]] scene. In November 1982, Exodus opened a show at San Francisco's [[Old Waldorf]] venue for [[Metallica]],[http://www.encycmet.com/live/26.shtml ENCYCLOPEDIA METALLICA – Concert Info: San Francisco, Old Waldorf California Nov 29, 1982] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604222532/http://encycmet.com/live/26.shtml |date=June 4, 2009 }} a then-relatively unknown (and unsigned) band from Los Angeles. As the band began playing more shows in Bay Area clubs, they gained a large, fervent fan base known for their violent concert behavior. In early 1983, Hammett left Exodus to join [[Metallica]] on the recommendation of manager / producer [[Mark Whitaker (record producer)|Mark Whitaker]], leaving Gary Holt to effectively take creative control of the band. Hammett was replaced short term by Mike Maung, followed by [[Evan McCaskey]], before the band finally found a permanent replacement in guitarist [[Rick Hunolt]]. Geoff Andrews also left to start an early incarnation of pioneering [[death metal]] band [[Possessed (band)|Possessed]], and was replaced by bass guitarist Rob McKillop. In the spring of 1984, Exodus entered Turk Street Studios with producer [[Doug Piercy]] to record demos of songs that would later appear on their debut album. The band was signed to New York-based Torrid Records and Exodus prepared to enter [[Prairie Sun Recording Studios]] that summer. ===''Bonded By Blood'' and rise in popularity (1984–1991)=== [[File:Exodus Rockharz 2018 30.jpg|thumb|left|Vocalist [[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]], who replaced [[Paul Baloff]], was a member of Exodus from 1986 to their first breakup in 1994, and again from 2002 to 2004. He rejoined the band once again in 2014.]] The band recorded their first album, ''[[Bonded by Blood]]'', in the summer of 1984 with the bands manager [[Mark Whitaker (music producer)|Mark Whitaker]] producing. 1984 concert photos from Exodus shows at [[Aquatic Park (Berkeley)|Aquatic Park]]'s Eastern Front Metal Festival (with [[Slayer]] and [[Suicidal Tendencies]]) and [[Bay Area thrash metal#Ruthie's Inn, Berkeley|Ruthie's Inn]] (with [[Megadeth]] and Slayer) were included on the album sleeve inserts. Originally titled ''A Lesson in Violence'', the album was not released until April 1985 amidst creative and business setbacks. Whilst ''Bonded By Blood'' is considered a highly influential [[thrash metal]] album today, critics have regarded the delay in its release as having hindered the impact the album could have had. As Allmusic reviewer Eduardo Rivadavia would later write in his review for the album: "Had it been released immediately after it was recorded in 1984, Exodus' ''Bonded by Blood'' might be regarded today alongside [[Metallica]]'s ''[[Kill 'Em All]]'' as one of the landmark albums responsible for launching the thrash metal wave."{{cite web|author=Eduardo Rivadavia |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bonded-by-blood-mw0000192933 |title=Bonded by Blood - Exodus | Songs, Reviews, Credits |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date= |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} Exodus promoted the album by going on tour with [[Venom (band)|Venom]] and [[Slayer]]. Four songs from their performance of April 5, 1985 at Studio 54 in New York City were filmed and released on home video as ''Combat Tour Live: The Ultimate Revenge''. The band subsequently toured or played selected shows with bands like [[Exciter (band)|Exciter]], [[Megadeth]], [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]], [[King Diamond (band)|King Diamond]], [[Possessed (band)|Possessed]], [[Dirty Rotten Imbeciles|D.R.I.]], [[Nuclear Assault]] and [[Hirax]]. Shortly after touring for ''Bonded by Blood'' was complete, Paul Baloff was fired from the band allegedly due to his behavior related to alcohol and substance abuse, and was replaced by [[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]], who had previously been the lead vocalist for Legacy, an early incarnation of fellow Bay Area thrashers [[Testament (band)|Testament]]. Baloff went on to form the band Piranha in 1987. Exodus' line-up remained stable for the recording of their next two albums, and the underground success attained with ''Bonded by Blood'' would lead to the group's signing to [[Sony Music|Sony]]/[[Combat Records]], who released the band's second effort ''[[Pleasures of the Flesh]]'' in 1987. The album was engineered by then-unknown [[Sylvia Massy]], who would go on to produce two releases by progressive rock band [[Tool (band)|Tool]]. In support of ''Pleasures of the Flesh'', Exodus toured with the likes of [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]], [[Celtic Frost]], [[M.O.D.]], [[Lȧȧz Rockit]] and [[Testament (band)|Testament]]. ''[[Fabulous Disaster]]'', the group's third full-length album, was released in 1989. A [[music video]] for the song "[[The Toxic Waltz (song)|The Toxic Waltz]]" would receive consistent rotation on [[MTV]]'s ''[[Headbangers Ball]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.revolvermag.com/magazine/article/the-history-of-american-thrash |title=The History of American Thrash |publisher=[[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver.com]] |accessdate=September 19, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125083043/http://www.revolvermag.com/magazine/article/the-history-of-american-thrash |archivedate=November 25, 2010 }} While promoting ''Fabulous Disaster'', Exodus embarked on the [[Headbangers Ball Tour|Headbangers Ball]] tour with [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]] and [[Helloween]], which brought the band to a wider audience. After the success of ''Fabulous Disaster'', Exodus signed to [[Capitol Records]] in 1989, who released the band's fourth album ''[[Impact is Imminent]]'' the following year. Prior to recording the album, Tom Hunting left the band for personal reasons; he was replaced by [[John Tempesta]] on drums. In 1991, the band released their first live album, ''[[Good Friendly Violent Fun]]'', which was recorded during their 1989 tour. ===''Force of Habit'', hiatus, and temporary reunion (1991–2000)=== [[File:Exodus Rockharz 2018 33.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Jack Gibson joined Exodus in 1997 as bass guitarist and has been with the group ever since.]] After the release of ''Good Friendly Violent Fun'', the band toured sporadically for a year. Bass guitarist McKillop was replaced by Michael Butler before the group recorded and released their next studio album titled ''[[Force of Habit]]'' in 1992. This album was something of a departure from the band's signature sound, containing several slower, "heavier" songs with less emphasis on the thrash aspect of their older material. The 11-minute song "Architect of Pain" is a good example of the change of direction, having a much slower, grindier feel than the usual high tempo thrash they had become known for. After touring for ''Force of Habit'' was completed, behind-the-scenes issues as well as a changing musical environment prompted the band to split up. Holt and Hunting formed the groove / thrash metal outfit Wardance in the mid 90's playing several shows around the Bay Area and recording a 4 song demo, but the group never gained momentum and eventually disbanded. Holt and Hunting reunited with Paul Baloff and Rick Hunolt for a short Exodus tour in 1997. The lineup was completed with Wardance bassist Jack Gibson. They released a live album titled ''[[Another Lesson in Violence]]'' recorded at the [[Trocadero Transfer]] in front of a home town audience. However, the group disbanded again the following year, in part due to a falling out with record label Century Media over the way promotion for the live album was handled, and over an aborted attempt at a live concert video which was filmed but never released due to a financial dispute. ===Second reformation, death of Paul Baloff and ''Tempo of the Damned'' (2001–2004)=== In 2001, Exodus reformed once again with the 1997 lineup, initially to play the [[Chuck Billy (vocalist)|Chuck Billy]] benefit [[Thrash of the Titans]] concert. There was talk of recording a new studio album and the band continued to play shows in and around the San Francisco Bay Area. However, on February 2, 2002, Paul Baloff died after suffering a stroke. Former vocalist Steve Souza was brought back into the band to finish the rest of their concert commitments. Although it appeared to outsiders that with Baloff's death Exodus would cease to exist, guitarist Gary Holt was determined to release a new studio album. The result was 2004's ''[[Tempo of the Damned]]'' released on [[Nuclear Blast Records]]. An oddity of the recording sessions was that one track, "Crime of the Century", was dropped under mysterious circumstances. The song chronicled Exodus's time under Century Media (of which Nuclear Blast is a subsidiary). Although it was publicly denied, rumors swirled that Century Media forced the song off the record. "Crime of the Century" was replaced with "Impaler", a song which was written when Kirk Hammett was still in the band, and was previously featured on the ''Another Lesson in Violence'' live record. ===Feud with Steve Souza, new members and ''Shovel Headed Kill Machine'' (2004–2006)=== [[File:Rob Dukes, Exodus 5.jpg|thumb|left|Vocalist [[Rob Dukes]] was one of three new members to join Exodus in 2005. He was part of the band until 2014.]] Steve Souza once again left the band due to business and personal differences in 2004.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/singer-zetro-souza-quits-exodus-again/ |title=Singer Zetro Souza Quits Exodus (Again) |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=September 13, 2004 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} This led to a feud between himself and Gary Holt, who subsequently issued a statement in which he was heavily critical of Souza, claiming he had suddenly left the band while on tour only a day before they were due to leave for a show in [[Mexico City]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-guitarist-fat-ass-zetro-souza-is-human-crap/ |title=Exodus Guitarist: 'Fat Ass' Zetro Souza Is 'Human Crap' |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=September 13, 2004 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} [[Exhumed (band)|Exhumed]] frontman Matt Harvey filled in for the Mexico City date{{cite web|title=EXHUMED Frontman Says Singing For EXODUS In Mexico Was An 'Honor'|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exhumed-frontman-says-singing-for-exodus-in-mexico-was-an-honor/|website=Blabbermouth}} and Steev Esquivel (ex-[[Defiance (band)|Defiance]] and [[Skinlab]]) played on the fall South American dates.{{cite web|title=SKINLAB Singer To Front EXODUS On Rescheduled South American Tour|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/skinlab-singer-to-front-exodus-on-rescheduled-south-american-tour/|website=Blabbermouth}} The band eventually found a permanent replacement in Rob Dukes. In 2005, Rick Hunolt left the band to focus on his family.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-confirm-guitarist-rick-hunolt-s-departure/ |title=Exodus Confirm Guitarist Rick Hunolt's Departure |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=August 4, 2005 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} He was replaced by [[Heathen (band)|Heathen]] guitarist [[Lee Altus]]. Tom Hunting also took leave of the band following a re-occurrence of the nervous problems that led to his temporary departure in 1989. Hunting was replaced with [[Paul Bostaph]] who had previously played with [[Slayer]] and [[Testament (band)|Testament]]. The revamped line up released the album ''[[Shovel Headed Kill Machine]]'' in 2005. The tour for the album led to extensive travel of the US, Europe, and Japan, as well as their first-ever visit to Australia. ===Reunion with Tom Hunting and the ''Exhibit'' albums (2007–2013)=== Tom Hunting returned to the band in March 2007 in time to record and release their 8th studio album ''[[The Atrocity Exhibition... Exhibit A]]''. They performed at the [[Wacken Open Air]] Festival in the summer of 2008. In April 2009, Exodus embarked on a co-headlining North American tour with [[Kreator]] and also featuring [[Belphegor (band)|Belphegor]], [[Warbringer]], and Epicurean. Exodus then went on tour supporting [[Arch Enemy]] along with [[Arsis]] and [[Mutiny Within]]. Exodus provided the voices of the customers at the Duncan Hills Coffee Shop and five of the sick people in [[Cartoon Network]]'s ''[[Metalocalypse]]''. Exodus released a re-recording of their 1985 debut album ''Bonded by Blood'' entitled ''[[Let There Be Blood]]'' in 2008. Gary Holt released the following statement about the band's decision to revisit their debut album: "After many years in the planning and discussion stage, we have finally completed the re-recording of 'Bonded By Blood'. We have decided to call it 'Let There Be Blood' and it is our way of paying homage to [late singer] Paul Baloff by showing how relevant these songs we had written together still are. We aren't trying to replace the original; that's impossible anyway. We are just giving these songs the benefit of modern production. It's something we talked about before Paul's death and it's always been important to us to do. We were super excited about entering the studio once again to record these classics, and now it's back to writing the next studio record!"{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} The album ''[[Exhibit B: The Human Condition]]'' was recorded in northern California with British producer Andy Sneap ([[Megadeth]], [[Arch Enemy]], [[Kreator]]) and released on Nuclear Blast Records in May 2010.{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=134987 |title=Exodus: New Album Pushed Back To May - Blabbermouth.net |website=Roadrunnerrecords.com |date=February 12, 2010 |accessdate=March 28, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606063706/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=134987 |archivedate=June 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} It was announced in January 2010 that Exodus was to be on [[Megadeth]]'s ''[[Rust in Peace]]'' 20th Anniversary tour along with [[Testament (band)|Testament]]. Exodus was featured on the cover of Decibel magazine's June 2010 issue, with a feature article on them. [[File:W00148 HellFest2012 Exodus.JPG|thumb|Exodus at 2012 Hellfest. This was one of the band's first shows with former guitarist [[Rick Hunolt]] (far right) in seven years.]] [[File:Exodus Rockharz 2018 12.jpg|thumb|Guitarist Lee Altus at Rockharz Open Air 2018]] [[File:Exodus Rockharz 2018 26.jpg|thumb|Drummer Tom Hunting at Rockharz Open Air 2018]] Exodus co-headlined with [[Kreator]], Suicidal Angels and [[Death Angel]] on the Thrashfest tour in late 2010 and were one of the headlining bands at Wacken Open Air 2011. Exodus toured with [[Rob Zombie]] and Slayer in 2011 on their Hell on Earth tour as the opening act. Gary Holt filled in for Slayer guitarist [[Jeff Hanneman]] during the tour after Hanneman contracted [[necrotizing fasciitis]] caused by a spider bite.{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=154594 |title=Slayer With Exodus Guitarist Gary Holt: First Video Footage From Soundwave Kick Off Show - Blabbermouth.net |website=Roadrunnerrecords.com |date=February 26, 2011 |accessdate=March 28, 2016 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Holt filled in for Hanneman again on Slayer's next tour in the summer of 2012. When Exodus also toured in the summer of 2012, guitarist [[Rick Hunolt]] (who left Exodus in 2005) filled in for Holt. [[Cannibal Corpse]] guitarist [[Pat O'Brien (guitarist)|Pat O'Brien]] also filled in for Holt during this time.{{cite web|url=http://www.guitarworld.com/exodus-be-joined-former-guitarist-rick-hunolt-upcoming-tour-dates |title=Exodus to Be Joined By Former Guitarist Rick Hunolt on Upcoming Tour Dates |publisher=Guitar World |date=December 3, 2013 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} On February 4, 2012 a Paul Baloff Memorial Reunion Concert was held at the Oakland Metro Opera House. Former and current Exodus members in attendance included [[Kirk Hammett]], Rick Hunolt, [[Gary Holt (musician)|Gary Holt]], Geoff Andrews, [[Lee Altus]], [[Rob Dukes]], [[Tom Hunting]] and Jack Gibson. It was the first time they had all played together since 1983. The band was confirmed for the [[Graspop Metal Meeting|Graspop Festival]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bravewords.com/news/183256 |title=EXODUS - 3-Guitar Attack Planned For Graspop Festival |website=Bravewords.com |date= |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} and for the [[Hellfest (French music festival)|Hellfest]] in June 2012. By the summer of 2012, Exodus had begun writing new material for their tenth studio album.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=176125 |title=Exodus Bassist On Randy Blythe Concert Incident: 'If You Come On Stage, You're Trespassing' |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=June 29, 2012 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=193189 |title=Exodus Taps Heathen Guitarist Kragen Lum For Select European Shows |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=July 31, 2013 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=179763 |title=Exodus Frontman Talks Next Album (Video) |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=September 21, 2012 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} On March 27, it was announced that the band entered the studio and were well into recording drum tracks, and the album was expected for a fall 2014 release. ===Reunion with Steve Souza, ''Blood In, Blood Out'' and upcoming eleventh studio album (2014–present)=== On June 8, 2014, Exodus announced that vocalist [[Rob Dukes]] had left the band,{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-parts-ways-with-singer-rob-dukes/ |title=Exodus Parts Ways With Singer Rob Dukes, Welcomes Back Steve 'Zetro' Souza |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=June 8, 2014 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} and was replaced by [[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]], making this the second time he had rejoined the band. Souza recorded vocals on the new album; the band's first to feature him since 2004's ''[[Tempo of the Damned]]''.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steve-zetro-souza-to-begin-recording-vocals-for-new-exodus-album-this-week/ |title=Steve 'Zetro' Souza To Begin Recording Vocals For New Exodus Album This Week |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=June 9, 2014 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steve-zetro-souza-a-lot-went-into-my-decision-to-rejoin-exodus/ |title=Steve 'Zetro' Souza: 'A Lot Went Into My Decision' To Rejoin Exodus |website=Blabbermouth.net |date=June 10, 2014 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} On June 26, 2014, Exodus announced on their official website that the album would be called ''[[Blood In, Blood Out (Exodus album)|Blood In, Blood Out]]'',{{cite web|title=Exodus Announces Exclusive VIP Packs for Upcoming Slayer Tour w/ Special Guests Suicidal Tendencies and Exodus|url=http://exodusattack.com/site/2014/06/26/exodus-announces-exclusive-vip-packs-for-upcoming-slayer-tour-w-special-guests-suicidal-tendencies-and-exodus/|website=Exodusattack.com|accessdate=June 29, 2014|date=June 26, 2014}} and it was released on October 14.{{cite web|title=Exodus To Release 'Blood In, Blood Out' Album In October|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-to-release-blood-in-blood-out-album-in-october/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=July 9, 2014|date=July 9, 2014}} ''Blood In, Blood Out'' received positive reviews from music critics upon its release, and peaked at {{abbr|No.|number}} 38 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], making it the band's highest chart position so far.{{cite web|title=Exodus' 'Blood In Blood Out' Cracks U.S. Top 40|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-blood-in-blood-out-cracks-u-s-top-40/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014|date=October 22, 2014}} [[Heathen (band)|Heathen]] Guitarist Kragen Lum was brought in to replace Gary Holt for several live dates while Holt performed and recorded with [[Slayer]].{{cite web|title=EXODUS Fill-In Guitarist KRAGEN LUM: 'They Treat Me Like Family' |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-fill-in-guitarist-kragen-lum-they-treat-me-like-family/}} Exodus performed at the Australian Soundwave Festival 2015, which was held across two weekends.{{cite web |author=|date=December 22, 2014 |title=Steel Panther, Exodus, Falling In Reverse, Etc. Added To 2015 'Soundwave Festival' |url=http://www.theprp.com/2014/12/22/news/steel-panther-exodus-falling-in-reverse-etc-added-to-2015-soundwave-festival/}} In April and May 2015, Exodus (along with [[Shattered Sun]]) supported [[Testament (band)|Testament]] on their ''[[Dark Roots of Thrash|Dark Roots of Thrash II]]'' tour.{{cite web|title=Testament And Exodus To Join Forces For 'Dark Roots Of Thrash II' Tour|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/testament-and-exodus-to-join-forces-for-dark-roots-of-thrash-ii-tour/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=February 17, 2015|accessdate=February 17, 2015}} Exodus then toured around Europe in June, including two nights at the [[Camden Underworld|Underworld]] in London. In June 2016, Steve Souza said that the band's next studio album could be released in late 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steve-zetro-souza-says-next-exodus-album-could-arrive-in-late-2017/|title=STEVE 'ZETRO' SOUZA Says Next EXODUS Album Could Arrive In Late 2017|publisher=Blabbermouth.net|accessdate=June 14, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steve-zetro-souza-its-time-for-exodus-to-start-putting-some-new-music-together/|title=STEVE 'ZETRO' SOUZA: It's Time For EXODUS To Start Putting Some New Music Together|publisher=Blabbermouth.net|accessdate=July 14, 2016}} In a May 2017 interview with Metal Wani, however, Souza stated that Exodus would enter the studio around October or November to begin recording the album for a March 2018 release.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-to-record-follow-up-to-blood-in-blood-out-in-the-fall/|title=EXODUS To Record Follow-Up To 'Blood In Blood Out' In The Fall|publisher=Blabbermouth.net|accessdate=May 5, 2017}} Drummer [[Tom Hunting]] added, "We're just structuring songs right now. I think we've probably got five or six maybe, and the makings for the rest of 'em — bits and pieces here and there."{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-has-five-or-six-songs-written-for-next-album-says-tom-hunting/|title=EXODUS Has 'Five Or Six' Songs Written For Next Album, Says TOM HUNTING|publisher=Blabbermouth.net|accessdate=June 10, 2017}} Souza explained that the material does not sound like a continuation of ''Blood In, Blood Out'' but rather "a lot of records put together, I think.", later describing it as "heavy as shit, though — really fucking heavy."{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exoduss-next-album-will-be-heavy-as-st-says-steve-zetro-souza/|title=EXODUS's Next Album Will Be 'Heavy As S**t,' Says STEVE 'ZETRO' SOUZA|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=June 21, 2017}} In an August interview, Souza stated that Exodus has been writing their new album, but added, "We obviously have to pay attention to [[Slayer]]'s schedule, because our [[Gary Holt (musician)|main guy]] plays in Slayer, so we have to pay attention to that. But I think they're coming to a bit of an end [of their touring cycle] where he's gonna have some time." He also said the band is "looking, probably, November, December, January — something like that — to get into the studio."{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-singer-on-next-album-were-writing-right-now/|title=EXODUS Singer On Next Album: 'We're Writing Right Now'|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=August 29, 2017}} In September, Hunting told Metal Wani that the album could include another collaboration with [[Kirk Hammett]] and a possible guest appearance by former guitarist [[Rick Hunolt]];{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exoduss-next-album-might-feature-guest-appearance-by-former-guitarist-rick-hunolt/|title=EXODUS's Next Album Might Feature Guest Appearance By Former Guitarist RICK HUNOLT|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=September 30, 2017}} Hunolt, Bostaph and Dukes joined the band on stage for a one-off reunion show in August.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-rejoined-by-rob-dukes-rick-hunolt-paul-bostaph-at-san-francisco-concert-video/|title=EXODUS Rejoined By ROB DUKES, RICK HUNOLT, PAUL BOSTAPH At San Francisco Concert (Video)|date=July 9, 2017|publisher=}} On September 29, 2017, Exodus were confirmed to appear at next year's Rockharz Open Air in Germany as one of the early bands noted for the main stage.{{cite web|url=http://exodusattack.com/site/2017/09/29/exodus-confirmed-for-rockharz-open-air-2018/|title=Exodus confirmed for Rockharz Open Air 2018}} In a January 2018 interview with Jimmy Kay of Canada's The Metal Voice, Holt confirmed that band was still writing songs for next studio album. He explained, "I'm taking my time. I'm super proud of it. It's heavy, of course. It's crushing. It's brutal. But it's something else — it's something altogether different."{{cite web|title=Will There Be A New SLAYER Studio Album? 'I'd Say It's A No,' Says GARY HOLT|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/will-there-be-a-new-slayer-studio-album-id-say-its-a-no-says-gary-holt/|work=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=January 25, 2018|accessdate=January 26, 2018}} When speaking to Metal Insider in February 2018, Souza said that fans would have to wait until at least the end of 2019 for a new studio album, mainly due to Holt's involvement in Slayer's farewell tour, "...we're not going to be able to record until that is finished. I'm speculating it's gonna take a year and a half or two years to do the one final thing, but I believe it's finished."{{cite web|url=http://www.metalinsider.net/interviews/interview-exodus-steve-zetro-souza-talks-cartoons-mr-pickles-thrashtacular-tour|title=Interview: Exodus’ Steve “Zetro” Souza talks cartoons, Mr. Pickles Thrashtacular tour, Exodus album update|author=El Prezidente|publisher=metalinsider.net|accessdate=February 22, 2018}} During a press conference at that summer's [[Hellfest (French music festival)|Hellfest]], Souza stated that the new album will "probably" be released in late 2019 or early 2020, and added, "I'll promise you this — I've heard songs, 'cause [Gary has] been writing, and the new Exodus is gonna be very violent and very heavy." In July 2018, Exodus announced that they would headline the 2018 installment of the MTV Headbangers Ball European Tour, along with [[Death Angel]], [[Suicidal Angels]] and [[Sodom (band)|Sodom]] from late November to mid-December.{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/exodus-to-headline-european-mtv-headbangers-ball-tour/|title=EXODUS To Headline European 'MTV Headbangers Ball Tour'|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=July 14, 2018}} ==Musical style, legacy and influences== Exodus has been credited as one of the pioneers of the [[thrash metal]] genre, which achieved mainstream popularity in the 1980s and early 1990s,{{cite web|url=https://www.goldenplec.com/live-reviews/exodus-in-the-button-factory-review/|title=Exodus in the Button Factory - Review • Live Review|publisher=goldenplec.com|date=August 15, 2013|accessdate=January 19, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://crypticrock.com/interview-steve-zetro-souza-of-exodus/|title=Interview - Steve "Zetro" Souza of Exodus|publisher=crypticrock.com|date=March 26, 2015|accessdate=January 19, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownmagazinenyc.com/exodus-singer-steve-zetro-souza-talks-playstation-theater-shows-with-king-diamond-next-album-disney-and-more/|title=Exodus singer Steve "Zetro" Souza talks Playstation Theater shows with King Diamond, next album, Disney and more|publisher=downtownmagazinenyc.com|date=November 12, 2015|accessdate=January 19, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fullinbloommusic.com/overkill-biography-dd-verni-blitz-ellsworth.html|title=Exodus - Biography - Bonded by Blood - Gary Holt - Paul Baloff - Kirk Hammett|website=fullinbloommusic.com|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} and is often credited as the first [[Bay Area thrash metal]] band to exist, predating [[Metallica]], who were originally from Los Angeles. Exodus' main influences include [[AC/DC]], [[Angel Witch]], [[Black Sabbath]], [[Deep Purple]], [[Diamond Head (band)|Diamond Head]], [[Iron Maiden]], [[Judas Priest]], [[Led Zeppelin]], [[Mercyful Fate]], [[Motörhead]], [[Nazareth (band)|Nazareth]], [[Ted Nugent]], [[Rainbow (rock band)|Rainbow]], [[Sweet Savage]], [[Thin Lizzy]], [[Tygers of Pan Tang]], [[UFO (band)|UFO]], [[Van Halen]] and [[Venom (band)|Venom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.getreadytorock.com/pure_metal/exodus.htm|title=Interview with Tom Hunting and Gary Holt of Thrash metal rock band Exodus|publisher=Get Ready to ROCK!|accessdate=January 26, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steve-zetro-souza-bands-don-t-survive-off-record-sales-anymore/|title=Steve 'Zetro' Souza: Bands Don't Survive Off Record Sales Anymore|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=September 8, 2012|accessdate=January 26, 2017}} [[Loudwire|Loudwire.com]] placed Exodus at number five on its list of the 10 Best Thrash Bands of All Time, calling them "The original kings of the Bay Area thrash scene", and saying that "While their uncompromising sound and uneven output in the coming decades kept world domination and platinum success ever at bay, you'd be hard passed to finger any other band, short of Slayer, perhaps, that's flown the thrash flag as proudly and unwaveringly as Exodus."{{cite web|url=http://loudwire.com/best-thrash-metal-bands/|title=10 Best Thrash Metal Bands of All Time|publisher=[[Loudwire|Loudwire.com]]|date=August 15, 2013|accessdate=January 26, 2017}} It has been debated whether or not Exodus belongs in the "Big Five" of thrash metal with [[Metallica]], [[Megadeth]], [[Slayer]] and [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]], due to their involvement with the early 1980s thrash metal scene. [[VH1]] stated, "Much is made of Thrash's Big Four: Metallica, Slayer, Megadeth, and Anthrax. True devotees know, however, that Big Five is the actual proper figure and that Exodus is the band that completes the quintet."{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/news/25827/10-greatest-thrash-metal-debut-albums/|title=10 Greatest Thrash Metal Debut Albums Of All Time|publisher=[[VH1|VH1.com]]|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=January 30, 2017}} Anthrax guitarist [[Scott Ian]] also stated that, "People talk about the 'Big Four' all the time, but back then it was really the 'Big Five' because Exodus were just as important and just as influential as everybody else." Megadeth founder [[Dave Mustaine]] said in a 1990 interview that the "Big Four" were Exodus, Slayer, Metallica and Megadeth, adding that "Exodus are a much better band – I really like Exodus. [[Gary Holt (musician)|Gary Holt]] and [[Rick Hunolt]] are really great guitar players. I like Scott Ian, but anyone else in that band kind of bores me. Having a disco thing is not what I think having a metal band is all about, and that guy had the audacity to say that he and I should together! I felt like saying what are you planning to do? Open a disco fashion shop?"{{cite web|url=http://megadeth.rockmetal.art.pl/articles_hotmetal1990.html|title=The Big Four|publisher=megadeth.rockmetal.art.pl|date=September 1990|accessdate=January 30, 2017}} Along with Ian and Mustaine,{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/anthrax-guitarist-says-expanded-big-four-should-include-exodus/|title=Anthrax Guitarist Says Expanded 'Big Four' Should Include Exodus|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=September 18, 2012|accessdate=January 30, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/dave-mustaine-says-exodus-would-have-been-most-qualified-candidate-for-expanded-big-four-2/|title=Dave Mustaine Says Exodus Would Have Been Most Qualified Candidate For Expanded 'Big Four'|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=July 6, 2013|accessdate=January 30, 2017}} Holt has agreed that Exodus should be included in the "Big Five" of thrash metal because they "were there at the start of thrash metal with Metallica in the real early '80s. Same thing with Megadeth because Mustaine was a part of Metallica's birth and he also created Megadeth."{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/gary-holt-says-big-four-should-be-expanded-to-include-exodus-we-were-there-at-the-start/|title=Gary Holt Says 'Big Four' Should be Expanded To Include Exodus: 'We Were There At The Start'|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=May 6, 2010|accessdate=January 30, 2017}} Frontman [[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]] has stated that the fact that Exodus was not included in the "Big Four" does not bother him, "I've heard that term many times and it doesn't really matter to me. It's not the truth. There's them, and Overkill, Testament and Exodus. You could also talk about [[Kreator]], [[Sodom (band)|Sodom]] and [[Destruction (band)|Destruction]], if you want to get down to it. It doesn't bother me — I'm content where I'm at."{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steve-zetro-souza-isnt-bothered-by-exodus-not-being-part-of-big-four-it-doesnt-really-matter-to-me/|title=STEVE 'ZETRO' SOUZA Isn't Bothered By EXODUS Not Being Part Of 'Big Four': 'It Doesn't Really Matter To Me'|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|date=September 5, 2017|accessdate=September 17, 2017}} ==Band members== {{main|List of Exodus members}} '''Current members''' * [[Gary Holt (musician)|Gary Holt]] – guitars, backing vocals (1981–1993, 1997–1998, 2001–present) * Jack Gibson – bass, backing vocals (1997–1998, 2001–present) * [[Lee Altus]] – guitars (2005–present) * [[Tom Hunting]] – drums (1980–1989, 1997–1998, 2001–2005, 2007–present), lead vocals (1979–1981) * [[Steve Souza|Steve "Zetro" Souza]] – lead vocals (1986–1993, 2002–2004, 2014–present) ==Discography== {{Main|Exodus discography}} * ''[[Bonded by Blood]]'' (1985) * ''[[Pleasures of the Flesh]]'' (1987) * ''[[Fabulous Disaster]]'' (1989) * ''[[Impact Is Imminent]]'' (1990) * ''[[Force of Habit]]'' (1992) * ''[[Tempo of the Damned]]'' (2004) * ''[[Shovel Headed Kill Machine]]'' (2005) * ''[[The Atrocity Exhibition... Exhibit A]]'' (2007) * ''[[Exhibit B: The Human Condition]]'' (2010) * ''[[Blood In, Blood Out (Exodus album)|Blood In, Blood Out]]'' (2014) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Exodus (band)|Exodus}} * {{Official website|http://www.exodusattack.com}} * [http://www.myspace.com/exodus Official MySpace page] * [http://www.metalfan.ro/articol.php?sectiune=2&id_doc=3166&lng=2 Exodus – Gary Holt interview @ Metalfan.ro – English] {{Exodus(band)}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Exodus}} [[Category:1979 establishments in California]] [[Category:Musical groups from the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1979]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1994]] [[Category:Musical groups reestablished in 1997]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1998]] [[Category:Musical groups reestablished in 2001]] [[Category:Musical quintets]] [[Category:Nuclear Blast artists]] [[Category:Political music]] [[Category:Thrash metal musical groups from California]]

{{Distinguish|Francisca Martínez}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{BLP sources|date=December 2015}} '''Francesca Martinez''' (born 1978) is an English comedian, writer and actress, born in London to a Spanish father and half-Swedish, half-English mother.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dugan |first=Emily |title=Francesca Martinez: A wobbly girl's battle against the last taboo |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/francesca-martinez-a-wobbly-girls-battle-against-the-last-taboo-1816861.html |work=The Independent |date=8 November 2009 |accessdate=8 November 2009}}</ref> She has [[cerebral palsy]] but prefers to describe herself as "wobbly".<ref>{{cite news |last=Bunbury|first=Stephanie |title=Wobbly but on the money |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/03/24/1048354540942.html |work=The Age |date=25 March 2003 |accessdate=8 November 2009}}</ref>
She has had many sell-out shows at the [[Edinburgh Festival]] and internationally, including the [[Melbourne Comedy Festival]], the [[Adelaide Fringe Festival]], the [[Perth Festival]], and the [[Just For Laughs]] Festival in Montreal. In 2014 she completed a 68-date UK/Ireland tour and has had multiple off-West End London runs at the [[Tricycle Theatre]], the [[Hackney Empire]], and the [[Soho Theatre]].
==Comedy== In 2000, Martinez became the first female comic to win the prestigious Daily Telegraph Open Mic Award at the Edinburgh Festival.
In 2003 she was listed in ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the 50 funniest acts in British comedy.
Martinez has performed sell-out shows in many countries including Australia, Canada, Ireland, [[Malaysia]], Singapore, South Africa, the United States, performing at [[Caroline's on Broadway]], [[92YTribeca]] and the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theater]] (all in New York City), and the [[Laugh Factory]] and the [[Comedy Store]] (both in Los Angeles). She also performed at the 2008 [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]], alongside [[Emma Thompson]].
Her tour 'WHAT THE **** IS NORMAL?!' clocked up over 130 dates around the world – winning a Fringe Media Network Award at the Edinburgh Fringe, as well as being nominated for Best Show at Dave's Leicester Comedy Festival and at the Perth Festival, Australia.
She has organised many charity shows featuring comedians such as [[Jo Brand]], [[Johnny Vegas]], [[Al Murray]], [[Richard Herring]], [[Stewart Lee]], [[Jeremy Hardy]], [[Lee Mack]], [[Mark Thomas]], [[Rhod Gilbert]], and [[Milton Jones]].
In 2014, her best-selling book 'WHAT THE **** IS NORMAL?! was published by [[Random House]] to critical acclaim. It has been nominated for the Chortle Comedy 'Best Book' Award and The Bread And Roses Radical Publishing Award.
==Television and radio== Before becoming a comedian Martinez appeared in the [[BBC]] children's drama series ''[[Grange Hill]]'' from 1994–1998, and has acted in other drama series such as ''[[Holby City]]''.
In August 2005 she appeared in the BBC sitcom ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]''.<ref>[[List of Extras episodes#Series 1 .282005.29]]</ref>
In April 2008 Martinez made global headlines when (live on [[Channel 4 News]]) she became the first [[Olympic torch]] bearer to pull out of the London relay in protest over China's treatment of Tibet.
In April 2009 she appeared on the [[BBC Radio 4]] stand-up comedy show, [[4 Stands Up]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00f4ptw |title=BBC Radio 4 – 4 Stands Up |publisher=BBC |date=7 May 2009 |accessdate=20 January 2013}}</ref>
In October 2012 she made her debut appearance on BBC Radio 4's topical panel show ''[[The News Quiz]]'', alongside regulars [[Jeremy Hardy]] and [[Sandi Toksvig]]. She appeared on ''The News Quiz'' again in January and July 2013.
Martinez has become a regular face on television, including appearances on ''[[The Frank Skinner Show]],'' in [[Ricky Gervais]] and [[Stephen Merchant]]'s comedy series ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'', ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'' [[BBC Three]], [[The Jonathan Ross Show]], ITV's [[Loose Women]], ''[[Free Speech]]'' BBC3, [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]'s ''[[The Saturday Night Show]]'' with [[Brendan O'Connor (media personality)|Brendan O'Connor]], ''[[Adam Hills Tonight]]'' and ''Spicks & Specks''.
==Campaigner== On 8 December 2012, Martinez launched a campaign ''War on Welfare''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefedonline.org.uk/disability-in-the-news/martinez-brings-star-quality-to-fresh-assault-on-coalition-s-war-on-welfare |title=Martinez brings star quality to fresh assault on coalition's 'war on welfare' – Disability in the News |publisher=The Fed Online |accessdate=21 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204013255/http://www.thefedonline.org.uk/disability-in-the-news/martinez-brings-star-quality-to-fresh-assault-on-coalition-s-war-on-welfare |archivedate=4 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> which pledged to get 100,000 supporters to sign a petition calling for an end to government cuts for [[disability benefits]] and an independent impact assessment of the government's welfare changes. The petition attracted 5,000 signatures in the first 48 hours,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/17717 |title=Welfare petition aims for ten thousand backers by New Year's Day |publisher=Ekklesia |accessdate=20 January 2013}}</ref> and achieved its target of 100,000 supporters on 30 November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/war-welfare-petition-100000-sign-2870513|title=100,000 sign War on Welfare petition asking for assessment of cuts to the sick and disabled|first=Steve|last=Robson|date=30 November 2013}}</ref>
An outspoken opponent of welfare reform by the government, she uses her public profile to raise issues about disability and fight for a fairer system. Martinez said: "As a disabled person in the media, I want to help give this issue a voice. It's morally wrong for the government to target those in need instead of saving money by targeting the real causes of this crisis – and close tax loopholes and regulate the financial sector. To me, it's a human rights issue."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.update.org.uk/news-detail.php?page=563|title=Disability Information Scotland|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130423211500/http://www.update.org.uk/news-detail.php?page=563|archivedate=23 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
She is patron of a number of charities.<ref name=Personally>{{cite web |url=http://www.personallyspeakingbureau.com/speaker/francesca-martinez/ |title=Francesca Martinez – Personally Speaking Bureau|accessdate=16 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=CAF>{{cite web|url=http://www.cafamily.org.uk/what-we-do/our-team/|title=Our Team – Contact a Family|accessdate=16 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604052159/http://www.cafamily.org.uk/what-we-do/our-team|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
She has challenged the government in numerous TV interviews, including on ''[[Newsnight]]'' and ''[[This Week (BBC TV series)|This Week]]''.
Martinez has become a respected social commentator, speaking at meetings and demos across the UK, as well as being a key part of the People's Assembly Against Austerity.
In 2015 she helped organise [[This Changes Everything (book)|This Changes Everything]], a one-day event on climate and social justice, with [[Naomi Klein]], [[Russell Brand]], and many other speakers. The event was streamed globally and aimed to kick-start a movement to unify the left against climate change.
In 2013 she was nominated for a Women in Public Life Award, and won the Public Affairs Achiever of the Year Award. In April 2014 she was named as one of Britain's most influential women in the BBC Woman's Hour power list 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Woman's Hour Power List 2014 – Game Changers|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03zy4m5/profiles|publisher=BBC Radio 4}}</ref> She was also nominated for Red Magazine's Woman of the Year Award 2014 and for a European Diversity Hero of the Year Award 2014.
In July 2015, Martinez endorsed [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s [[Jeremy Corbyn Labour Party leadership campaign, 2015|campaign]] in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2015|Labour Party leadership election]].<ref name="newstatesman">{{cite news |last=Bush|first=Stephen|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2015/07/25-campaign-groups-and-activists-back-jeremy-corbyn-labour-leader|title=25 campaign groups and activists back Jeremy Corbyn for Labour leader|work=[[New Statesman]]|date=29 July 2015|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref> In 2016, along with numerous other celebrities, she toured the UK to support Corbyn's bid to become [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]].<ref name="jc4pmtour">{{cite web |url=http://www.jc4pmtour.com/|title=#JC4PM|publisher=jc4pmtour|date=28 July 2015|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |last=Wilkinson|first=Michael|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/Jeremy_Corbyn/12134051/Celebrities-to-tour-Britain-in-Jeremy-Corbyn-For-Prime-Minister-musical-show.html|title=Celebrities to tour Britain in 'Jeremy Corbyn For Prime Minister' musical show|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=1 February 2016|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref> In September 2016, she performed at the Keep Corbyn rally in Brighton in support of [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s [[Jeremy Corbyn Labour Party leadership campaign, 2016|campaign]] in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|Labour Party leadership election]].<ref name="doncasterfreepress">{{cite news |last=Burke|first=Darren|url=https://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/tv-star-comedians-line-up-for-jeremy-corbyn-rally-in-doncaster-1-8090226|title=TV star comedians line up for Jeremy Corbyn rally in Doncaster|work= |location=Doncaster|publisher=''[[Doncaster Free Press]]''|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref>
