([[United States]]) |picture_format = |audio_format = |first_run = |first_aired = {{Start date|2011|4|3}} |last_aired = {{End date|2011|4|10}} |status = |preceded_by = |followed_by = ''[[The Kennedys: After Camelot]]'' |related = |website = http://www.kennedys-miniseries.com/ |production_website = http://www.muse.ca/en/the-kennedys.aspx }} '''''The Kennedys''''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]]-American television [[miniseries]] chronicling the lives of the famous political [[Kennedy family]], including key triumphs and [[Kennedy curse|tragedies]] it has experienced. It stars [[Greg Kinnear]], [[Barry Pepper]], [[Katie Holmes]], and [[Tom Wilkinson]] among others, and is directed by [[Jon Cassar]]. The series premiered in the [[United States]] in April 2011 on the [[ReelzChannel]] and on [[History (Canada)|History Television]] further north in [[Canada]]. ==Cast== *[[Greg Kinnear]] as [[John F. Kennedy|John F. "Jack" Kennedy]] *[[Barry Pepper]] as [[Robert F. Kennedy|Robert F. "Bobby" Kennedy]] *[[Katie Holmes]] as [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline Kennedy]] *[[Tom Wilkinson]] as [[Joseph P. Kennedy, Sr.]] *[[Diana Hardcastle]] as [[Rose Kennedy]] *[[Kristin Booth]] as [[Ethel Kennedy]] *[[Chris Diamantopoulos]] as [[Frank Sinatra]] *[[Charlotte Sullivan]] as [[Marilyn Monroe]] *[[Serge Houde]] as [[Sam Giancana]] *[[Enrico Colantoni]] as [[J. Edgar Hoover]] *Don Allison as [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] *Rothaford Gray as [[Abraham Bolden]] *[[Gabriel Hogan]] as [[Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr.]] * Ava Preston as Caroline Kennedy *Carson Reaume as David Kennedy ==Early criticism== ''The Kennedys'' was the subject of negative responses from historians based on early scripts, including charges of historical inaccuracy and presenting an unflattering depiction of the titular family.{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/greg-kinnear-will-play-john-f-kennedy-in-history-channel-miniseries/ |title=Greg Kinnear Will Play John F. Kennedy in History Channel Miniseries |last=Itzroff |first=Dave |work=The New York Times |date=April 28, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} On February 16, 2010 the website [http://www.stopkennedysmears.com stopkennedysmears.com] was registered by filmmaker [[Robert Greenwald]] as part of the critical response to ''The Kennedys''.{{cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/stopkennedysmears.com |title=Whois Record For StopKennedySmears.com |accessdate=December 18, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/17/arts/television/17kennedy.html?_r=1 |title=Even Before Filming, Kennedy Series Stirs Anger |last=Itzroff |first=Dave |work=The New York Times |date=February 16, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} On February 24, 2010 Dave Itzkoff of ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that historian [[David Talbot]], whose recent book had been used as source material for the miniseries, had joined those preemptively criticizing ''The Kennedys''.{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/24/another-historian-criticizes-the-kennedys/| title=Another Historian Criticizes 'The Kennedys' |last=Itzroff |first=Dave |work=The New York Times |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} [[Ted Sorensen]] (1928-2010), former presidential aide and speech writer for 35th President [[John F. Kennedy]] (1917-1963, served 1961-1963), described the script as a "character assassination".{{cite news|url=http://www.wilshireandwashington.com/2010/02/historians-challenge-joel-surnows-kennedys.html |title=Historians Challenge Joel Surnow's "Kennedys" |work=wilshireandwashington.com |last=Johnson |first=Ted |date=February 16, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} At the time of all of this criticism, the miniseries had not yet even been cast.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/02/16/kennedy-tv-series-causing_n_464656.html |title=Kennedy Series For 'History Channel' Called Inaccurate, Vindictive|first=Sam |last=Stein |work=Huffington Post |date=February 16, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} In an interview published in ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' on June 17, 2010, [[Joel Surnow]] addressed the complaints, saying, "they looked at early drafts of script that don't even resemble the final draft. It was way too early for them to comment on it."{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jun/17/business/la-fi-ct-facetime-20100617/2 |title='Kennedys' miniseries producer Joe Surnow breaking rules again |last=Chmielewski |first=Dawn C. |work=The Los Angeles Times |date=June 17, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} However, as the British newspaper ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' put it: "With Greg Kinnear as Mr. Kennedy, Katie Holmes as his First Lady and a budget of $30 million dollars, expectations had been high. Now, it is widely considered a disaster on the eve of its airing on the ReelzChannel beginning on Sunday. The History Channel decided to drop the series from its schedule in January 2011, stating that it was "not a fit" for the network. There then followed a humiliating and very public quest to find another channel that would air it."{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8420643/Kennedy-TV-series-to-finally-air-in-US-amid-scathing-reviews.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Toby | last=Harnden | title=Kennedy TV series to finally air in U.S. amid scathing reviews | date=April 1, 2011}} ==Production== Casting the main roles was announced on April 29, 2010 by director Cassar via his Twitter account.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/joncassar/status/13031406427 |title=Twitter / Jon Cassar: My Kennedys cast, Greg Kin ... |last=Cassar |first=Jon |date=April 29, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} The miniseries was filmed in [[Toronto, Ontario]], Canada between June and September 2010, and was produced by Canadian independent studio [[Muse Entertainment Enterprises]] and Joel Surnow's production company. ''The Kennedys'' is the first original scripted series made for [[History Television]].{{cite news|url=http://playbackonline.ca/2010/04/29/kennedys-20100429/?print=yes |title=History, Muse ready Kennedys |last=Strauss |first=Marise |publisher=Playback.ca |date=April 29, 2010 |accessdate=December 18, 2010}} The budget for ''The Kennedys'' was $25 million though reports later described it as a $30 million production. The miniseries was primarily written by Stephen Kronish, who previously worked with Surnow and Cassar on ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''. Historians associated with the production were Steven M. Gillon, author of the book ''The Kennedy Assassination – 24 Hours After'', and [[Robert Dallek]].''Entertainment Weekly'', April 1, 2011. ==Broadcast history== ===Canada=== On December 16, 2010, [[Shaw Media]] announced that there would be a special screening of the miniseries to be held on March 3, 2011 in Toronto.{{Cite pressrelease|url=http://www.shawmedia.ca/advertising/broadcast/television/research/inside_track/2010/1216/The%20Kennedys.pdf |title=The Kennedys |publisher=[[Shaw Media]] |date=December 16, 2010 |accessdate=February 1, 2011}} The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] reported on January 13, 2011 that [[Shaw Media]] would be showing ''The Kennedys'' in March 2011, but they were uncertain about whether it would remain on [[History (Canada)|History Television]] or be moved to their broadcast network [[Global Television Network|Global]], or one of their other cable channels such as [[Showcase (Canadian TV channel)|Showcase]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2011/01/11/kennedy-muse.html |title=Kennedys miniseries seeks new US buyer |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |date=January 11, 2011 |accessdate=January 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113164304/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2011/01/11/kennedy-muse.html |archivedate=January 13, 2011 }} The miniseries had been scheduled on History in two-hour segments at 9:00 pm beginning on March 6, 2011 and continuing for three subsequent Sundays. John Doyle, television critic for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' reported on January 26, 2011 that ''The Kennedys'' will be shown on History Television starting on March 9, 2011.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/television/john-doyle/its-misery-when-your-show-disappears/article1882586/ |title=It's misery when your show disappears |author=[[John Doyle (critic)|Doyle, John]] |work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada |date=January 26, 2011 |accessdate=February 1, 2011}} Six days later, it was reported that Stan Hubbard, CEO of ReelzChannel, claimed that part of his acquisition deal for US rights would be worldwide premiere rights, forcing an uncertain delay in the originally announced television premiere in March 2011 on History Television in Canada. On February 1, 2011 Shaw Media announced its revised schedule for the miniseries, which was to be shown on History Television in four two-hour segments beginning on April 10, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv-eh.com/2011/02/01/the-kennedys-premieres-on-history-television-april-10/ |title=The Kennedys premieres on History Television April 10 |last=Wild |first=Diane |work=TV Eh? |date=February 1, 2011 |accessdate=February 3, 2011}} ===United States=== On January 7, 2011, the cable channel [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History]] announced that it would not show ''The Kennedys'' in the United States, stating "this dramatic interpretation is not a fit for the History brand."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/history-channel-pulls-kennedys-last-69529 |title=EXCLUSIVE: History Channel Pulls 'The Kennedys'; Says Controversial Miniseries 'Not a Fit' |last=Belloni |first=Matthew |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=January 7, 2010}} Michael Prupas, president of Muse Entertainment and executive producer of the miniseries, issued a statement on January 10, in which he addressed the claims of inaccuracies: "The decision of the History Channel not to broadcast the show was made long after the executives of the Channel as well as the Channel's resident historian (who is a Kennedy expert) had read and approved all of the scripts and viewed and approved all of the final cuts of all of the episodes. Furthermore, our Errors and Omissions Insurer's attorneys reviewed all the scripts and edited episodes – and they have cleared all of the episodes for broadcast."{{cite web|url=http://www.kennedys-miniseries.com/muses-statement-regarding-the-kennedys/|title=Muses's Statement Regarding the Kennedys |last=Prupas |first=Michael |publisher=[[Muse Entertainment]] |date=January 14, 2011 |accessdate=October 2, 2011}} Director Jon Cassar said at the January 2011 [[Television Critics Association]] gathering in Los Angeles that he believed the reason the miniseries would not be shown by History and other US broadcasters was because powerful people within the United States connected to the Kennedy family took exception to it and used their political and other influence to prevent the showing.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/article/920427--kennedys-director-says-they-always-made-requested-changes |title=Kennedys director stunned by decision not to air series |last=Brioux |first=Brian |work=Toronto Star |date=January 13, 2011 |accessdate=January 15, 2011}} Joel Surnow, the series' executive producer, attributed the cancellation to pressure exerted by the Kennedys on the board of History's owners, [[A&E Television Networks]] and [[The Walt Disney Company]]. Surnow stated: "It happened at the board level. I don't want to mention anyone by name. It's very simple to say that certain board members are friends with the Kennedys."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/producer-joel-surnow-says-kennedys-170135%20 |title=Producer Joel Surnow Says 'Kennedys' Was Nearly Killed Because of His Political Views (Exclusive) |last=Belloni |first=Matthew |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=March 22, 2011 |accessdate=April 1, 2011}} Other reports pinpointed Kennedy family members [[Maria Shriver]] and [[Caroline Kennedy]] as the leaders of the campaign to stop the show, targeting Disney executive [[Anne Sweeney]].{{cite news|url=http://my.telegraph.co.uk/expat/sebastian1111/10142503/how-%E2%80%98the-kennedys%E2%80%99-avoided-assassination/ |title=How 'The Kennedys' avoided assassination |last=Doggart |first=Sebastian |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=April 1, 2011 |location=London}} On January 12, [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] passed on the US broadcasting rights for ''The Kennedys''.{{cite news|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/01/showtime-passes-on-the-kennedys/ |title=Showtime Passes On 'The Kennedys' |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=January 12, 2011 |accessdate=January 12, 2011}} Two days later it was reported that [[DirecTV]]'s [[The 101 Network]] was considering acquiring the miniseries.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/01/exclusive-directv-in-talks-to-air-the-kennedys/ |title=Exclusive: DirecTV In Talks To Air The Kennedys |last=Mitovich |first=Matt Webb |publisher=[[TVLine]] |date=January 14, 2011 |accessdate=January 25, 2011}} Ten days later, on January 24, 2011, it was announced that The 101 Network also passed on airing the show.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/directv-passes-kennedys-74545 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wBM6hM2m |title=DirecTV Passes on 'The Kennedys' |last=Belloni |first=Matthew |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=January 24, 2011 |accessdate=February 1, 2011 |archivedate=February 1, 2011}} On February 1, 2011, [[ReelzChannel]] acquired US broadcast rights to ''The Kennedys'' and announced their intention to show the miniseries between April 3 and 10, 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kennedys-miniseries-lands-home-air-95123 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wBKnt6et |title='Kennedys' Miniseries Lands Home, Will Air on ReelzChannel (EXCLUSIVE) |last=Belloni |first=Matthew |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=February 1, 2011 |archivedate=February 1, 2011 |accessdate=February 1, 2011}} Other US cable channels reported to have declined acquisition of the miniseries are [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] and [[Starz (TV channel)|Starz]]. ''Mediaweek'' reported that [[Hubbard Broadcasting]], the owners of ReelzChannel, took a big risk in purchasing the rights to the miniseries by paying an estimated $7 million for the broadcast rights and spending an additional $10 million in advertising.{{cite news|url=http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/content_display/news/cable-tv/e3i443f4a966d7d908cacb2c0c85a9e44bd |title=Reelz Goes for Broke |last=Shields |first=Mike |work=[[MediaWeek]] |date=April 4, 2011 |accessdate=April 10, 2011}} ===United Kingdom=== In the United Kingdom, [[History (UK TV channel)|History UK]] was scheduled to screen the miniseries beginning on April 7, 2011. Tom Davidson, managing director of AETN-UK stated on the History website: "Securing the UK premiere of ''The Kennedys'' is a major coup for the History channel. Bringing to life the story of America's most iconic family, the drama is a bold and epic account of the Kennedy dynasty and we are delighted that viewers in the UK will get to see it on History first."{{cite web|url=http://tv.sky.com/history-announces-kennedys-uk-premiere-date |title=History Releases Kennedys UK Premiere Date |publisher=[[BSkyB]] |date=March 7, 2011 |accessdate=April 1, 2011}} Writing in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', TV director [[Sebastian Doggart]] commented: {{quote|This is an amazing example of double standards. How can AETN call the series "not a fit" for the US History Channel, but describe this "bold and epic account" as "a major coup" for the UK's History channel? AETN has suggested that the reason is that the US History Channel is especially concerned about its historically truthful brand. So what is the channel broadcasting this Sunday night, in the same time-slot as ''The Kennedys'' over on Reelz? The answer: ''[[Ax Men]]'', a reality show about loggers; and ''[[Swamp People]]'', another reality show about alligator hunters.}} Also in the UK, the [[BBC]] presented the series, beginning Friday, June 17, 2011, in both standard definition and [[High-definition television|HD]]. === Other countries === ; 2011 The series began broadcasting in [[Serbia]] on [[B92]] beginning on May 6, 2011;{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/tv/najava.php?id=1790 |title=Kenedijevi – TV B92 |publisher=B92.net |accessdate=April 2, 2012}} in Republic of Ireland on [[RTÉ One]] beginning on May 21, 2011; and in Australia on [[ABC1]], beginning on May 22, 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/katie-and-camelot-too-hot-to-handle-20110518-1ers2.html|title=Katie and Camelot: too hot to handle|last=Atkinson|first=Fran|date=May 19, 2011|work=The Age |location=Australia|accessdate=May 19, 2011}} In Italy the series started on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] on June 7, 2011. Rose mourns Joe's death in 1969, and Jackie marries [[Aristotle Onassis]]. |LineColor = f7c121 }} |} ==Critical reception== ===Canada=== [[John Doyle (critic)|John Doyle]] of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' wrote, "it is awful – truly, mind-bogglingly tedious television." "The series (made in Canada with Muse Entertainment as the production company) looks cheap and sticks to the TV dramatics level of an afternoon soap opera." Doyle makes note of the predominantly Canadian cast and hopes they get a career boost but that the miniseries was "boosted by a fake controversy" and believes that "the American History Channel dropped it because it's bad TV."{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/television/john-doyle/the-kennedys-if-politics-were-this-boring-no-one-would-do-it/article1970426/ |title=The Kennedys miniseries: If politics were this boring, no one would do it |author=[[John Doyle (critic)|Doyle, John]] |work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada |date=April 5, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2011}} ===United States=== The miniseries met with a mixed reception from US critics. Based on 24 reviews from mainstream critics, it received an average score of 50/100 at [[Metacritic]], indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-kennedys|title=The Kennedys|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=April 9, 2011}} Mark A. Perigard of the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' noted that there is no mention of Joseph and Rose Kennedy's other children, including the future Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] and [[Kathleen Cavendish, Marchioness of Hartington]], and that it feels as though you are watching "through the prism of the ''[[Fringe (TV series)|Fringe]]'' universe". Perigard found it to be "an absorbing, addictive drama, with some authentic performances" but not history.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/television/reviews/view/2011_0401american___history_kennedys_rather_liberal_with_facts/ |title='Kennedys' rather liberal with 'facts' |last=Perigard |first=Mark A. |work=[[Boston Herald]] |date=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2011}} [[Alessandra Stanley]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote a joint review of ''The Kennedys'' and of ''[[The Borgias (2011 TV series)|The Borgias]]'', which premiered the same day. In addressing the circumstances of the premiere she wrote, "There is something wonderfully Kennedyesque about a backroom campaign to discredit a series that claims the Kennedy White House had more than its share of backroom shenanigans." Stanley found the miniseries to be well made though at times cheesy, but that its strongest point is Tom Wilkinson as Joseph Kennedy, whom she describes, in tandem with [[Pope Alexander VI|Rodrigo Borgia]], as "A ruthless, tyrannical striver (who) grasps for power, promoting his sons to establish his rule and cement his legacy".{{cite news|url=http://tv.nytimes.com/2011/04/01/arts/television/borgias-on-showtime-and-kennedys-on-reelzchannel-review.html?ref=alessandrastanley |title=The Power Brokers: Fathers, Sons, Dynasties |author=[[Alessandra Stanley|Stanley, Alessandra]] |work=The New York Times |date=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2011}} [[Hank Stuever]] of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' found the miniseries "all ends up being as harmless as a game of Kennedy paper dolls" and the assassinations to be portrayed quite gently considering how violent Joel Surnow's show ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'' is. Stuever describes the screenplay as clumsy and find the miniseries "sketches its characters with the precision of a fat Sharpie marker" and cautions those who recall the time that they may be troubled watching the story "through Surnow and company's mean-spirited gaze". In moving on to review ''[[Camelot (TV series)|Camelot]]'', which premiered three days before ''The Kennedys'', Stuever wrote, "If you check your calendar, we're nearing the 50th anniversary of JFK's death, which makes him, his family and Cabinet members as fair game as [[King Arthur]], [[Guinevere]], [[Merlin]] and the gang, who've had their stories updated, revised and pillaged for centuries now."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/tv-review-about-the-kennedys-like-the-kennedys-but-never-fully-the-kennedys/2011/03/30/AFHzXQCC_story.html |title=TV review: About the Kennedys, like the Kennedys, but never fully 'The Kennedys' |author=[[Hank Stuever|Stuever, Hank]] |work=The Washington Post |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2011}} ===U.S. Nielsen ratings=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#e0e0e0;" ! | Episode(s) ! | Title(s) ! | Date ! | Total viewers

{{Chinese|c=西千佛洞|p=Xī Qiānfó Dòng|pic=W1000BuddhaCaves Cave 7 w wall (Northern Wei).jpg|piccap=Celestial figures above serial Buddhas in the Thousand Buddha tradition, west wall, Cave 7 ([[Northern Wei]]); the ritual practice of ''foming'' (佛名), or naming the Buddhas, may lie behind such representations (names appear on the white labels beside each figure in the lower two tiers)<ref>{{cite book |title=Mogao Cave 254: a case study in early Chinese Buddhist art (PhD dissertation) |author=Abe, Stanley K. |publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley]] |year=1989 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Ancient Buddhism in Japan, I |author=De Visser, M. W |year=1935 |publisher=[[Brill Publishers|Brill]] |pages=377–93}}</ref>}} The '''Western Thousand Buddha Caves''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|西|千|佛|洞}}|p=Xī Qiānfó Dòng}}) is a Buddhist cave temple site in [[Dunhuang]], [[Gansu Province]], China. The site is located approximately 35 km southwest of the urban centre and about the same distance from the [[Yangguan|Yangguan Pass]]; the area served as a staging post for travellers on the [[Silk Road]].<ref name="pamphlet">{{cite book |script-title=zh:敦煌西千佛洞石窟 |trans-title=Dunhuang Western Thousand Buddha Caves |language=Chinese, English, Japanese |editor=Zhang Xuerong |publisher=甘肃人民美术出版社 |year=1998 |isbn=9787805882314 |pages=4–5}}</ref> It is the western counterpart of the [[Mogao Caves]], also known as the "Caves of the Thousand Buddhas" after the founding monk Yuezun's vision in 366 of "golden radiance in the form of a thousand Buddhas".<ref name="Whitfield">{{cite book |title=Cave Temples of Mogao: Art and History on the Silk Road |author=Whitfield, Roderick (''et al.'') |publisher=[[Getty Conservation Institute]] |year=2000 |isbn=0892365854 |pages=5, 9}}</ref> The caves were excavated from the cliff that runs along the north bank of the Dang River. A number have been lost to floods and collapse; some forty are still extant. Twenty-two decorated caves house 34 [[polychrome]] statues and 800 m<sup>2</sup> of wall paintings, dating from the [[Northern Wei]] to the late-[[Yuan Dynasty|Yuan]] and early-[[Ming Dynasty|Ming]] Dynasties (sixth to fourteenth centuries).<ref name="pamphlet"/> The site was included within the 1961 designation of the [[Mogao Caves]] as a [[Major Site Protected for Its Historical and Cultural Value at the National Level|Major National Historical and Cultural Site]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sach.gov.cn/tabid/96/InfoID/16/frtid/134/Default.aspx |title=国务院关于公布第一批全国重点文物保护单位名单的通知 (1st Designations) |date=3 April 1961 |publisher=[[State Administration of Cultural Heritage]] |language=Chinese |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref>
==Caves== [[File:Pelliotcave2.jpg|thumb|left|170px|[[Paul Pelliot|Pelliot]] examining manuscripts in the [[Dunhuang manuscripts|Library Cave]] at [[Mogao Caves|Mogao]]]] A manuscript from the [[Dunhuang manuscripts|Library Cave]], dating to the [[Five Dynasties]] and now at the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France|Bibliothèque nationale]] in Paris, documents the early history of the site ([[Paul Pelliot|P]] 5034): according to the ''Domain Record of Shazhou Dudu Prefecture – Shouchang County'', "60 ''[[Li (unit)|li]]'' east of the county is a very old inscription that says '[[Later Han (Five Dynasties)|Han Dynasty]]… made a small Buddha niche; the common people gradually built more'".<ref name="pamphlet"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://idp.bl.uk/pages/collections_fr.a4d |title=French Collections |publisher=[[International Dunhuang Project]] |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8307389s |title=Pelliot Manuscript 5034 |publisher=[[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] |accessdate=30 April 2012}}</ref> Since Shouchang County, modern Nanhu<!--Not easy to disambiguate, it seems to be adandoned http://dsr.nii.ac.jp/photograph/dunhuang/0195.html.en --> Village, is the location of the [[Yangguan|Yangguan Pass]] along the [[Hexi Corridor]], it is understood that this is a reference to the origins of the Western Thousand Buddha Caves.<ref name="pamphlet"/>
The decorated caves are in three main sections: Caves 1–19 at the west end of the cliff, approximately one kilometre from the modern reservoir; Cave 20 in the middle of the site, near the second [[floodgate]]; and Caves 21 and 22 at the eastern end of the cliff.<ref name="pamphlet"/> Most of the sculptures were restored in a different style during the [[Qing Dynasty]] and the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]].<ref name="pamphlet"/> The caves at the western end of the site have had aluminium doors and glass partitions installed more recently with the intention of mitigating the [[Preventive conservation#Definition|environmental causes of deterioration]].<ref name="pamphlet"/> Some of the paintings at the far east end of the site, distant from the custodians' lodgings, have been [[Detachment of wall paintings|detached and remounted]] in a cave at [[Mogao Caves|Mogao]].<ref name="pamphlet"/> The ruined state of the main Buddha image in [[Northern Wei]] Cave 7 enables the construction techniques to be seen: layers of earthen [[Plaster|render]] over an [[Armature (sculpture)|armature]] of branches and reeds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dha.ac.cn/0403/section.htm |script-title=zh:西千佛洞第7窟 |trans-title=Western Thousand Buddha Caves – Cave 7 |language=Chinese |publisher=[[Mogao Caves|Dunhuang Academy]] |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref> The loss of upper paint layers also reveals the linear grid used to set out the design of the Thousand Buddhas on the cave walls.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qwdo8vWeQr8C&pg=PA104#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Performing the Visual: The Practice of Buddhist Wall Painting in China and Central Asia |author=Fraser, Sarah Elizabeth |publisher=[[Stanford University Press]] |year=2003 |isbn=9780804745338 |page=104}}</ref>

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Whitehousenight.jpg | title=White House at Night | artist=Vincent van Gogh | year=1890 | catalogue={{Flatlist}} *[[Jacob Baart de la Faille|F766]] *[[Jan Hulsker|JH2031]] {{Endflatlist}} | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=59 | width_metric=72.5 | height_imperial=23.2 | width_imperial=28.5 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=[[Hermitage Museum]], Saint Petersburg }} '''''White House at Night''''' is an oil on canvas painting created on 16 June 1890 in the small town of [[Auvers-sur-Oise]] by [[Vincent van Gogh]], six weeks before his death. It is displayed at the [[Hermitage Museum]], St. Petersburg.
According to the Hermitage Museum, the painting "expresses the great psychological tension under which Van Gogh found himself"; two of the windows, considered the "eyes" of a home, are rendered with "alarming" red splashes, while the star, a sign of fate, is seen as symbolic of van Gogh's anguish.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arthermitage.org/Vincent-van-Gogh/White-House-at-Night.html|title=White House at Night|publisher=Arthermitage.com}}</ref>
It is thought that van Gogh painted ''White House at Night'' around 8:00 PM due to the position of the "star" in the painting. Astronomers Donald Olson and Russell Doescher from the [[Texas State University-San Marcos]] calculated that the star in the painting must be Venus which was bright in the evening sky in June 1890.<ref name="BBC1">{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1209614.stm|title= Venus pinpoints Van Gogh painting|date=8 March 2001}}</ref> The house is the same one depicted in ''[[:File:Van Gogh - Blühende Kastanienbäume1.jpeg|Blossoming Chestnut Tree]]''.<ref name="Heugten2007">{{cite book|last=Sjraar|first=|title=Vincent Van Gogh: Drawings : Van Gogh Museum|year=2007|publisher=Van Gogh Museum|page=416}}</ref>
The painting has a turbulent history. It was exhibited in Switzerland several times during the 1920s, but in the late 1920s disappeared into the private collection of German industrialist [[Otto Krebs]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://digital.library.txstate.edu/bitstream/handle/10877/4034/fulltext.pdf|work=Sky and Telescope|author=Olson, Donald & Doescher, Russell|title=Identifying the "star" in a long-lost van Gogh|date=April 2001}}</ref> Many of his acquisitions were of a style which was soon to be labelled "[[degenerate art]]" by the Nazis, which contributed towards the already publicity-shy Krebs keeping his collection secret.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/30/arts/hermitage-in-its-manner-displays-its-looted-art.html?pagewanted=all|title=Hermitage, in Its Manner, Displays Its Looted Art|work=New York Times|date=30 March 1995|first=Steven|last=Erlanger}}</ref>
Thought to have been lost after [[World War II]], the painting languished in the Hermitage archives for fifty years before resurfacing in 1995 as part of an exhibition displaying artworks looted by the [[Soviets]] at the end of the war.<ref name="BBC1" /> Three other van Gogh's from Kreb's collection were also shown: ''[[:File:Gogh,_Vincent_van_-_Landscape_with_House_and_Ploughman.jpg|Landscape with House and Ploughman]]'', ''[[:File:Vincent van Gogh - Morning, going out to Work.jpg|Morning: Going out to Work (After Millet)]]'', and the ''[[:File:Vincent van Gogh - Portrait de Madame Trabuc.jpg|Portrait of Madame Trabuc]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.art-antiques-design.com/art-theft/542-otto-krebs-collection|title=Otto Krebs Collection: Spoils of War or Plunder in Peace?| date= 20 September 2015|publisher=AAD}}</ref>
